content.question: Four different blocks are attached to either one or two horizontal springs and can move with negligible friction on a horizontal surface, as shown. Each spring has the same spring constant, and each block has a mass of either <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> or <math alttext="2 m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> as indicated. Each block is displaced the same distance from its equilibrium position. <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="F sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> are the restoring forces exerted on blocks <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, and <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, respectively. How do the restoring forces compare to each other?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1 equals F sub 2, which is greater than F sub 3, which equals F sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="F sub 2 equals F sub 4, which is greater than F sub 1, which equals F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="F sub 3 is greater than F sub 1, which equals F sub 4, which is greater than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="F sub 3 equals F sub 4, which is greater than F sub 1, which equals F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 3 equals F sub 4, which is greater than F sub 1, which equals F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
